author: abehazbunjr
title: Market-Agnostic Recursive Royalties
description: 慈善団体がエクスポージャーに悩む一方で、CNFTの市場では、あらゆる状況に対応できないロイヤリティーメカニズムの合意と適用に苦労しています。

f6_assessments.q0:
This draft proposal of about 69 words is requesting $12k to create a minting service for NFTs on Cardano with a notion of incentivized sharing. That's about it.
With such few detail it's impossible to assess anything. It seems that this proposal should have been withdrawn but was not.
f6_assessments.q1:
Draft proposal. A link to a GitHub account is given but almost nothing else. We also know that the proposer is a Plutus pioneer.
The proposer completed the questionnaire telling the required information was provided while it is not the case.
f6_assessments.q2:
69 words cannot provide enough information for any Catalyst proposal.
It is written in the proposal that a plan was to be provided by the end of the week on 2021-11-28 but ultimately was not.

f6_assessments.q0:
Interesting idea definetly can largely impact the cardano adoption, I believe that it would attract new people.

Yet the proposal is in a form of a draft, more work to be done, or information to be provided.

Rating given 3 due to the lack of information.
f6_assessments.q1:
The experience provided seems reasonable, yet more people should be involved in such a project. This information is missing, therefore it poses a question of how well it would proceed.

More information is required. 

Rating given 3.
f6_assessments.q2:
This information is completely missing, yet I can imagine that we would be able to audit it. 

Due to the fact, I am assessing the information in the proposal, I put a rating of 2 - cause the information is not there, yet it would be possible. 

More information is required.

f6_assessments.q0:
I think I am competent to assess this proposal as I have been active in project Catalyst since fund 4 and I have experience analyzing business requirements from 7 years of delivering software as a QA engineer.
The problem statement is confusing because it makes 2 seemingly completely unrelated assertions: that charities struggle with exposure and that CNFT markets struggle to agree on royalty mechanisms. What is the link between the two?
The solution describes an interesting idea, that of automatic purchases of CNFT's, but what are dynamic payto addresses and how would they incentivize sharing? What would be shared? There is a lot being said in this statement, including a minting service and UI that would make all this possible, but there are no explanations given on who would do this, how they would do it and how they would advertise it.
Due to the general nature of the challenge, this proposal might fit in it since in the end it would be a new type of application I suppose, but there are too many unanswered questions and missing pieces of information here (for example the lack of any type of KPI or concrete goal) for me to be able to agree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer mentions that he is a Plutus student and the notes on the provided github do reflect this, but there does not seem to be much other activity there, especially in the fast few months. Aside from this, two years of Cardano experience are mentioned - this is too vague in my opinion. Try to detail what exactly you have done in the ecosystem in the future. Lastly, 14 years of experience of web analytics and managing large technical projects are mentioned, but no references are provided to verify this. It's a good idea to try to add at least a Linkedin page to back you up.
I strongly disagree that this proposal can be implemented successfully, due to the lack of information on the team who would work on this, no details on how the budget would be used, no risk analysis and no plan outlining the technical approach and the usage of resources concretely. As the proposers mentioned, the full plan was due at the end of November, but it does not seem to have made it unfortunately.
f6_assessments.q2: There are no KPI's or a roadmap, due to the proposal being unfinished, so I strongly disagree that this proposal is auditable.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is still just an idea, there is no specific product description as well as a plan to implement this proposal. Therefore, it is almost impossible to assess the impact of the proposal on the community
f6_assessments.q1:
"Proposer is a full-time Plutus student with two years of Cardano experience and 14 years of web analytics and managing large technical projects. When I check github, it shows a project with some activity but no information about the proposer.
Besides, the absence of a specific product description and proposal implementation plan has reduced the feasibility of this proposal."
f6_assessments.q2: More information of what is going to be delivered, when and what success looks like and how it would be measured needs to be provided.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal focuses on minting service and UI that can create CNFTs that "sell themselves" recursively, with dynamic pay to addresses that incentivize sharing. The idea is quite abstract. Theoretically, without a detailed plan, I can not say if this proposal fit the challenge. In case this proposal needs to be completed in the future, the proposer should pay attention to Defining keywords, such as: "sell themselves". Based on the given information, I can not agree with this proposal's impact and would give it a score of 2.
f6_assessments.q1: I am convinced by the idea description, and the proposer's relevant experience [a full-time Plutus student with two years of Cardano experience and 14 years of web analytics and managing large technical projects] with external link to prove [Github], which is proof of feasibility for this idea. However, I am not convinced by an empty plan. So, I can see some proof of feasibility in the idea, not in the plan. Therefore, definitely, based on the given information, I disagree with this proposal's feasibility and would give it a score of 2.
f6_assessments.q2: This proposal is incomplete, transparency can not be guaranteed. Therefore, I don't have much advice, except that: the proposer needs to pay attention to the principle: judgment, information must be correctly associated with evidence and documents. As a result, I strongly disagree with this proposal's auditability and would give it a score of 1.

solution: 再帰的に "自分自身を売る "CNFTを作ることができる鋳造サービスとUIで、共有を促すダイナミックなPaytoアドレスを備えています。
experience: 私はPlutusのフルタイムの学生で、2年間のカルダノの経験と、14年間のウェブ分析と大規模な技術プロジェクトの管理の経験があります。
